title: Get OO CA certificate
content:
The steps to get the Operations Orchestration (OO) CA certificate is different depending on whether you have installed a complete certificate chain in OO or in an external load balancer used for the suite.

We recommend that you install a complete certificate chain in a production environment. A properly configured suite should send all intermediate certificates to the client. 

Using an incomplete certificate chain isn't good in production and is a common misconfiguration that causes an "unable to get local issuer certificate" or "unable to find valid certification path to requested target" error during an SSL/TLS handshake between the client and server. The certificate chain can't be verified back to a local issuer certificate (which means it's in the client's certificate store). 

 If you're unsure whether you have a complete certificate chain or not:
  • You can use the procedure of scenario 2 as it also works for scenario 1.
  • (Only if the suite system is public) You can also check the suite certificate by using Qualys' SSL Server Test. If the tool reports "This server's certificate chain is incomplete.", it means you must use the steps for scenario  2. However, this method requires your suite to be reachable from the internet.

Scenario 1 (recommended)

In this scenario, you have a complete certificate chain installed, either on an external load balancer or directly in the suite if you don't use an external load balancer. This is the recommended scenario.

In this scenario, obtaining the root CA certificate of OO is good enough. Follow these steps to obtain the root CA certificate:

  1. Open the OO URL from a web browser:
    • For on-premises deployment, open the URL https://<OO_Host>:<OO_Port>. Example: https://myoohost.example.com:9443
    • For EKS deployment:
      • The OO login URL is the URL of the OO public load balancer in the format https://<OO_public_load_balancer_fqdn>:<OO_public_load_balancer_port>. See Configure load balancers for OO.
      • The OO integration URL is the URL of the OO internal load balancer in the format https://<OO_internal_load_balancer_fqdn>:<OO_internal_load_balancer_port>.
  2. Click the lock icon before the URL on the address bar.
  3. Click Certificate.
  4. On the Certification Path tab, select the site root certificate (the topmost one), and then click View Certificate. If this tab shows only one certificate, the View Certificate option isn't available and you need to directly go to the next step.
  5. On the Details tab, click Copy to File.
  6. In the Certificate Export Wizard, click Next.  
  7. Select the Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) format, click Next.
  8. Follow the rest of the instructions and export the certificate.

Scenario 2

In this scenario, you have an incomplete certificate chain installed. This means you installed the server certificate only, either on an external load balancer or directly in the suite if you don't use an external load balancer. 

Use the following steps to get the suite CA certificate chain (excluding the server certificate, which isn't required). 

  1. Open the OO URL from a web browser:
    • For on-premises deployment, open the URL https://<OO_Host>:<OO_Port>. Example: https://myoohost.example.com:9443
    • For EKS deployment:
      • The OO login URL is the URL of the OO public load balancer in the format https://<OO_public_load_balancer_fqdn>:<OO_public_load_balancer_port>. See Configure load balancers for OO.
      • The OO integration URL is the URL of the OO internal load balancer in the format https://<OO_internal_load_balancer_fqdn>:<OO_internal_load_balancer_port>. 
  2. Click the lock icon before the URL on the address bar.
  3. Click Certificate.
  4. Click the Certification Path tab to see the certificate chain.

    The following figure shows an example.

    In this example, as with many certificates nowadays, the suite certificate is signed by one or more CAs, also known as a "chained root". The topmost CA is the root, and any CAs under the root are known as intermediate CAs. We need the two topmost items, DigiCert and DigiCert SHA2 High Assurance Server CA. These are the CAs we need to export from the suite and import into the integration endpoints. 

  5. Select one CA in the chain and click the View Certificate button to open this certificate.
  6. On the Details tab of this new window, click the Copy to File button.
  7. In the Certificate Export Wizard, click Next.
  8. Select the Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) format, click Next.
  9. Follow the rest of the instructions and export the certificate.
  10. Repeat steps 5~9 for each of the other CAs in the chain until all CAs are exported. Note that the bottom one in the certificate chain is the actual server certificate, which you don't need to export.  Now, you should have all CAs exported onto your PC. In this example, you should have 2 CA files.
